content:
TITLE: Declarations and Destructuring in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows variable declaration syntax and destructuring patterns in Civet. Includes const, let, var declarations and various array/object destructuring patterns.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Declarations
const x = 1
let y: number = 2
var z: string = "3"
x := 1 // const x = 1
y .= 2 // let y = 2

// Destructuring
[ a, b ] := x
[ ..., last ] := x
[ first, ...rest ] := x
[ first, ..., last ] := x
[ first, ...middle, last] := x

{ a, b } := c
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pattern Matching in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates Civet's pattern matching syntax using switch statements with various patterns including regex and destructuring.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/index.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
switch x
  0
    console.log("zero")
  /^\s+$/
    console.log("whitespace")
  [{type: "text", content}, ...rest]
    console.log("leading text", content)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Plugin Options Interface for Civet Integration
DESCRIPTION: TypeScript interface defining all available configuration options for the Civet plugins, including declaration generation, TypeScript handling, and custom transformations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/source/unplugin/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
interface PluginOptions {
  emitDeclaration?: boolean
  declarationExtesion?: string
  implicitExtension?: boolean
  outputExtension?: string
  ts?: 'civet' | 'esbuild' | 'tsc' | 'preserve'
  typecheck?: boolean | string
  cache?: boolean
  parseOptions?: {
    comptime?: boolean
    coffeeCompat?: boolean
    // ... any other Civet configuration option
  }
  transformOutput?: (
    code: string,
    id: string
  ) => TransformResult | Promise<TransformResult>
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pipeline Operators in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows different pipeline operator usage including basic pipes, fat pipes for chaining operations, and pipe expressions with shorthand functions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/index.md#2025-04-17_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
data
  |> Object.keys
  |> console.log
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
document.createElement('div')
||> .className = 'civet'
||> .appendChild document.createTextNode 'Civet'
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
a |> & + 1 |> bar
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Arrow Functions in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates arrow function syntax in Civet. Shows both fat arrow (=>) and thin arrow (->) functions, which are equivalent to lambda and function expressions respectively.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Arrow Functions
inc := (x) => x + 1
add := <T>(a, b): T => a + b

// Thin arrow -> is equivalent to `function`
f := (this: ctx, a, b) ->
  ctx.log a, b if ctx.debug
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: This, Instance, and Type Checking in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows shortcuts for 'this' references, instanceof checks, and typeof checks in Civet. The @ symbol represents 'this' and <? provides shorthand for both instanceof and typeof checks.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// this
this
// shorthand
@ // this
@x // this.x

// instance of and typeof shorthand
x instanceof y
x <? Y // x instanceof y
typeof x === "string"
x <? "string" // typeof x === "string"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: JSX in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates JSX syntax in Civet with shorthand attributes and component composition.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/index.md#2025-04-17_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: jsx
CODE:
```
function Listing(props)
  <h1 #heading>Hello Civet!
  <ul .items>
    <For each=props.items>
      (item) =>
        <li .item {props.style}><Item {item}>
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: TypeScript Compiler Configuration and File Handling
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of TypeScript compiler host setup with default compiler options and file caching system. Defines configuration for TypeScript compilation including module resolution and target settings.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
ts, {CompilerOptions} from typescript

DefaultCompilerOptions : CompilerOptions :=
  allowNonTsExtensions: true
  allowJs: true
  target: ts.ScriptTarget.Latest
  moduleResolution: ts.ModuleResolutionKind.NodeJs
  module: ts.ModuleKind.CommonJS
  allowSyntheticDefaultImports: true
  experimentalDecorators: true

fileCache : Record<string, any> := {}

createCompilerHost := (options: CompilerOptions, moduleSearchLocations : string[]) ->
  fileExists := (fileName: string) : boolean ->
    fileCache[fileName]?

  readFile := (fileName: string) ->
    fileCache[fileName]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Conditionals and Relationals in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows logical operators and relational expressions in Civet, including the 'and'/'or' aliases for '&&'/'||' and the 'is' alias for '==='. Also demonstrates chained relational operators.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Conditionals
x && y
x and y // x && y
x || y
x or y // x || y

// relationals
x === y
x is y // x === y
x < y
x > y
// Chained relationals
x < y < z // x < y && y < z
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Conditional Statements and Loops in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows if, unless, while, and for loop syntax in Civet. Demonstrates conditionals without parentheses or braces and various loop constructs for arrays and objects.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// if conditions
if x < 3
  "it's small"

if x > 11
  "it's big"

unless paused
  run()

// loops
while x < 10
  f(x)
  x++

for item of items
  update item

for item, index of items
  update item if index > 0

for key, value in object
  log key, ':', value

for own key in object
  log `my ${key}`
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: String Literals in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates various string literals in Civet including single quotes, double quotes, template strings, and block strings. Block strings automatically dedent based on common indentation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// strings
"I'm a string"
'I\'m also a string'
`I'm a ${template} string`

// Block Strings
"""
  Block strings
  will dedent
"""

'''
  They work with all kinds of
  strings
'''

```
  I will dedent by removing
  common indentation
```
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Function Application in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates both explicit and implicit function application in Civet. Shows how parentheses can be omitted in many cases, creating a more concise syntax.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Function application
f(x)
f(a, g(x))
f(...args, cb)

// Implicit application
f x // f(x)
f a, b, c // f(a, b, c)
f g x // f(g(x))
f a, b c // f(a, b(c))
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Single-Argument Function Shorthand
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates various shorthand syntaxes for single-argument functions including property access and operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/index.md#2025-04-17_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
x.map .name
x.map &.profile?.name[0...3]
x.map &.callback a, b
x.map &+1
x.map -&
x.map [&, &.toUpperCase()]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Property Access in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows various property access syntaxes in Civet. Includes dot notation, quoted properties for special names, template string properties, array indexing, and length shorthand.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Property Access
json.x.y
json.'long property'
json.`${movie} name`
matrix.0.0
array.-1
array.#
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: JSX Syntax in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows JSX syntax in Civet with enhanced features like better binding using props and @ prefix. Also demonstrates optional closing tags and class shorthand syntax.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// JSX
// Better binding
<button props.click> Click Me </Button>
<button @click> Click Me Also </Button>

// Closing is optional
<div>
  <button> Click Me

// class shorthand
<.items>
  <.item>
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Civet in Build Tools
DESCRIPTION: Example of configuring Civet options within build tools using the civetPlugin. This approach allows for global configuration that overrides even config files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/config.md#2025-04-17_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
civetPlugin({
  parseOptions: {
    objectIs: true,
    implicitReturns: false,
    tab: 2,
  },
})
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Await Operators in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows shorthand syntax for common Promise operations like Promise.all, Promise.allSettled, and Promise.race using the await operator with dot notation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Await operators
await.allSettled promises
await.all promises
await.race promises
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pipe Operator in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows the pipe operator (|>) for sequential operations. Allows passing the result of one expression as an argument to the next function, supporting await, method calls, and function shorthands.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Pipe operator
data
|> Object.keys
|> console.log

x.length
|> & + 1
|> .toString()

fetch url
|> await
|> .json()
|> await
|> return

// Pipe assignment
data |>= .content
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Decorator Syntax in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Civet uses @ for 'this', 'static', and 'constructor' shortcuts, so decorators need to be written with @@ prefix. Decorators also cannot appear on the same line as methods.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
@@Object.seal
class Civet
  @name = "Civet"
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
class Civet
  @@description translate "Caffeine time!"
  drink()
    @fetch @coffeeCup
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Block Shorthand and Conditional Declarations in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows block shorthand for map/filter operations using the placeholder ($) and conditional declaration patterns. Enables concise syntax for common operations and pattern matching.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Block shorthand
people.map .name // people.map($ => $.name)
numbers.filter & % 2 is 0
// numbers.filter($ => $ % 2 === 0)

// Conditional declarations
throw error if { error } := result

if [, dir, base] := /^(.*\/)?([^\/]*)$/.exec file
  console.log dir, base
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Object Globs in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates object glob syntax for concisely extracting or creating objects with specific properties. Enables property spread, nested access, and destructuring in a compact form.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Object globs
point = data{x,y}
point = data.{x,y};
point.{x,y} = data
point3D = { point.{x,y}, z: 0 }
complex := obj.{x:a, b.c()?.y}
merged := data.{...global, ...user};
data.{a, b, ...rest} = result
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Length Shorthand in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows shorthand syntax for length operations using the # symbol. Simplifies working with array lengths in indexing, assignment, and calculations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_20

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// this.length shorthand
@[#] = item
@[index %% #]
floor # / 2
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Thick Pipes in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the thick pipe (||>) for method chaining and side effects. The thick pipe forwards the original value instead of the result of each operation, enabling fluent chaining on the same object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Thick Pipes
array
||> .pop()
||> .push 5
||> .sort()
||> .reverse()

count |> & + 1
||> console.log
|> & * 2
||> console.log

url |> fetch |> await
||> (response) => console.log response.status
|> .json() |> await
||> (json) => console.log "json:", json
|> callback
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pattern Matching in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates pattern matching in switch statements. Allows matching against string literals, regular expressions, and other patterns without explicit comparison operators.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Pattern Matching
switch s
  ""
    console.log "nothing"
  /\s+/
    console.log "whitespace"
  "hi"
    console.log "greeting"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Custom Infix Operators
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to define and use custom infix operators in Civet.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/index.md#2025-04-17_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
operator {min, max} := Math
value min ceiling max floor
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pattern Destructuring in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows advanced pattern matching with destructuring in switch statements. Enables matching against object structures and extracting specific properties in a concise syntax.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Pattern destructuring
switch x
  [{type: "text", content: /\s+/}, ...rest]
    console.log "leading whitespace"
  [{type: "text", content}, ...rest]
    console.log "leading text:", content
  [{type}, ...rest]
    console.log "leading type:", type
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Switch Statements in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows switch statement syntax in Civet. The 'when'/'then' keywords are used instead of 'case'/'break', and indentation defines the scope of each case.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Switch
switch dir
  when '>' then civet.x++
  when '<'
    civet.x--
    civet.x = 0 if civet.x < 0
  else
    civet.waiting += 5
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Civet with Vite
DESCRIPTION: Setup code for integrating Civet with Vite bundler by adding the Civet plugin to the Vite configuration file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/source/unplugin/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// vite.config.ts
import { defineConfig } from 'vite'
import civetVitePlugin from '@danielx/civet/vite'

export default defineConfig({
  // ...
  plugins: [
    civetVitePlugin({
      // options
    }),
  ],
})
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Slicing and Splicing in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows array slicing and splicing syntax in Civet. Enables extracting start, middle, or end portions of arrays using range notation, and modifying arrays with slice assignment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// slicing and splicing
start := numbers[..2]
mid := numbers[3...-2]
end := numbers[-2..]
numbers[1...-1] = []
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Postfix Conditionals and Loops in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use postfix conditionals and loops in Civet. These allow for more concise expressions when the condition or loop body is simple.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Postfix loops/conditionals
f(x) if x
log name for name of names
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Civet with ESBuild
DESCRIPTION: Setup code for integrating Civet with ESBuild by adding the Civet plugin to the ESBuild configuration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/source/unplugin/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import esbuild from 'esbuild'
import civetEsbuildPlugin from '@danielx/civet/esbuild'

esbuild
  .build({
    // ...
    // sourcemap: true, // build and link sourcemap files
    plugins: [civetEsbuildPlugin()],
  })
  .catch(() => process.exit(1));
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implicit Return Behavior in Civet Functions
DESCRIPTION: All functions in Civet implicitly return the value of their last statement. This can be disabled by adding a semicolon, declaring a void return type, or adding an explicit return statement.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
function more(x) {
  x+1
}
function hello() {
  console.log("Hello world!")
}
function hello() {
  console.log("Hello world!");
}
function hello(): void {
  console.log("Hello world!")
}
function hello() {
  console.log("Hello world!")
  return
}
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
(x) => x + 1
(x) => x + 1;
=> console.log("Hello world!")
=> console.log("Hello world!");
(x) => {
  if (x > 5)
    "large"
  else
    "small"
}
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
"civet -implicitReturns"
function hello() {
  console.log("Hello world!")
}
=>
  console.log("Hello world!")
(x) => x + 1
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Civet with Webpack
DESCRIPTION: Setup code for integrating Civet with Webpack bundler by adding the Civet plugin to the Webpack configuration file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/source/unplugin/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const civetWebpackPlugin = require('@danielx/civet/webpack').default;

module.exports = {
  // ...
  plugins: [
    civetWebpackPlugin({
      // options
    }),
  ],
};
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Single-Argument Arrow Functions in Civet vs JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: In Civet, arrow functions with a single argument require parentheses, unlike JavaScript where they're optional. This allows zero-argument functions to omit parentheses entirely in Civet.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
(x) => x + 1
```

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
x => x + 1
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
=> console.log("Hello")
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
createEffect => console.log(signal())
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Range Literals in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates range literal syntax for creating arrays of sequential values. Supports character ranges, numeric ranges, reverse ranges, and exclusive end ranges.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/cheatsheet.md#2025-04-17_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// Range literals
letters := ['a'..'f']
numbers := [1..10]
reversed := [10..1]
indices := [0...array.length]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Transpiling Civet in ESM NodeJS
DESCRIPTION: JavaScript code snippet demonstrating how to transpile Civet code to TypeScript or JavaScript within an ESM NodeJS application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/getting-started.md#2025-04-17_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
import {compile} from "@danielx/civet"
const tsCode = await compile(civetCode)
const tsCodeWithSourceMap = await compile(civetCode, {inlineMap: true})
const jsCode = await compile(civetCode, {js: true})
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Indentation Significance in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Civet uses indentation to define code blocks, requiring consistent indentation. This differs from JavaScript where indentation is cosmetic and doesn't affect program execution.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
(x) =>
  console.log("Hello")
  x+1
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
if (condition)
  console.log("condition holds")
  console.log("condition still holds")
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Integrating Civet with esbuild
DESCRIPTION: JavaScript code snippet demonstrating how to integrate Civet with esbuild using the Civet unplugin.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/getting-started.md#2025-04-17_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
import esbuild from 'esbuild'
import civetPlugin from '@danielx/civet/esbuild'

esbuild.build({
  // ...
  // sourcemap: true, // build and link sourcemap files
  plugins: [
    civetPlugin({
      // Options and their defaults:
      // emitDeclaration: false,         // generate .d.ts files?
      // declarationExtension: '.civet.d.ts', // extension for .d.ts files
      // implicitExtension: true,        // import "./x" checks for x.civet
      // outputExtension: '.tsx',        // appended to .civet internally
      // ts: 'civet',                    // TS -> JS transpilation mode
      // typecheck: false,               // check types via tsc
      // cache: true,                    // cache compilation results based on mtime, useful for watch
      // config: null,                   // Civet config filename; null to skip
      // parseOptions: {                 // directives to apply globally
      //   comptime: false,              // evaluate comptime blocks
      // },
    })
  ]
}).catch(() => process.exit(1))
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Operator Spacing Rules in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Civet requires consistent operator spacing due to its implicit function call syntax. Unary operators cannot have spaces after them, binary operators need symmetric spacing, and certain operators have specific spacing requirements.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
x+y    // addition
x + y  // addition
x +y   // unary
//invalid: + y
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
x/y/z      // division
x / y / z  // division
x /y/ z    // regular expression
//invalid: x /y
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
x<y>z      // comparison
x < y > z  // comparison
// JSX:
x <y> z
//invalid: x <y
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Civet with tsup
DESCRIPTION: TypeScript configuration file for integrating Civet with tsup, a zero-config TypeScript bundler.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/getting-started.md#2025-04-17_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
// tsup.config.ts
import { defineConfig } from 'tsup';
import civetPlugin from '@danielx/civet/esbuild';

export default defineConfig({
  entryPoints: ['main.civet'],
  esbuildPlugins: [
    civetPlugin({
      // options
    }),
  ],
});
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: JSX Implementation in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Civet requires proper indentation for JSX children to enable automatic tag closing. It also automatically combines consecutive JSX tags at the same indentation level into JSX fragments.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
<div>
  <h1>Hello</h1>
  <p>Text</p>
"not inside div anymore"
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
"civet coffeeJSX"
<div>
  <h1>Hello</h1>
  <p>Text</p>
still inside div
</div>
```

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
<h1>Hello</h1>
<p>Text</p>
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Advanced ESLint Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Complex ESLint configuration demonstrating explicit file matching and plugin configuration for Civet files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/integration/eslint/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import civetPlugin from "eslint-plugin-civet"
import js from "@eslint/js"

export default [
  // Enable recommended rules for all files
  js.configs.recommended,
  // Load plugin and enable processor for .civet files
  {
    files: ["**/*.civet"],
    plugins: {
      civet: civetPlugin,
    },
    processor: "civet/civet",
    // Here is where you would override specific rules.
    // We provide an `overrides` rule set that disables rules that
    // don't work well with Civet output.
    ...civetPlugin.configs.overrides,
  },
]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Civet with Local Directive
DESCRIPTION: Example of specifying Civet configuration options using a local directive at the top of a Civet file. This enables object comparison with Object.is, disables implicit returns, and sets tab width to 2 spaces.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/config.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
"civet objectIs -implicit-returns tab=2"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing Decorators in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Example of Civet's decorator syntax using @@ instead of @ for class and method decorators, as @ is reserved for this.id and static fields/methods.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
@@classDecorator
class X
  @@methodDecorator
  method() {}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: TypeScript ESLint Configuration (CommonJS)
DESCRIPTION: CommonJS configuration file for using typescript-eslint with Civet files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/integration/eslint/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const civetPlugin = require("eslint-plugin-civet/ts")

module.exports = [
  // Rules from eslint.configs.recommended
  ...civetPlugin.configs.jsRecommended,
  // Rules from tseslint.configs.strict
  ...civetPlugin.configs.strict,
]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Civet via API
DESCRIPTION: Example of using the Civet compilation API to set configuration options. This demonstrates how to compile Civet code with specific parse options.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/config.md#2025-04-17_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import {compile} from "@danielx/civet"
const code = await compile(civetCode, {
  parseOptions: {
    objectIs: true,
    implicitReturns: false,
    tab: 2,
  },
})
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Custom Civet Compiler Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Example of customizing the Civet compiler configuration with additional options.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/integration/eslint/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import { civet } from "eslint-plugin-civet"
const civetPlugin = civet({
  parseOptions: {
    // coffeeCompat: true,
    // ...
  },
})
// rest as before
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Loading Civet Config Files via API
DESCRIPTION: Example of using the Civet config module to find and load configuration files. This demonstrates how to locate config files in directories and use them for compilation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/config.md#2025-04-17_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import { findInDir, findConfig, loadConfig } from "@danielx/civet/config"
// Look for standard name for config file in specified directory
const path1 = await findInDir(process.cwd())
// Look for standard name for config file in specified directory or ancestors
const path2 = await findConfig(process.cwd())
// Load config file from specified path
const config = await loadConfig(path)
// Pass config to compile
const code = await compile(civetCode, config)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Braced Block Rules in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Civet allows braced blocks but has restrictions to avoid conflicts with object literals. One-line braced blocks must be on the same line as their control statement.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
// block
if (x) { y }
// not a block
if (x)
{ y }
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Gulp Task for Civet Compilation in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to set up a Gulp task to compile Civet files. It uses the gulp-civet plugin to process .civet files and output them as JavaScript files. The task includes options for specifying the output file extension and enabling JavaScript mode.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/integration/gulp/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const civet = require('gulp-civet');

gulp.task('civet', () => {
  gulp.src('./src/*.civet')
  .pipe(civet({
    extension: '.js',
    js: true,
  })
  .pipe(gulp.dest('./dist'));
});
```

TITLE: Configuring TypeScript for Civet
DESCRIPTION: Example tsconfig.json file for using TypeScript with Civet, including recommended compiler options.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/getting-started.md#2025-04-17_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "strict": true,
    "jsx": "preserve",
    "lib": ["es2021"],
    "moduleResolution": "bundler",
    "forceConsistentCasingInFileNames": true,
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true
  },
  "ts-node": {
    "transpileOnly": true,
    "compilerOptions": {
      "module": "nodenext"
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Installing and Running Civet CLI Commands
DESCRIPTION: Command-line instructions for installing Civet globally and running various operations including REPL, file compilation, and script execution.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# Install
npm install -g @danielx/civet
# Run Civet code directly in a REPL
civet
# Transpile typed Civet code into TypeScript in a REPL
civet -c
# Compile Civet source file to TypeScript
civet < source.civet > output.ts
# Execute a .civet script
civet source.civet ...args...
# Execute a .civet source file in node
node --import @danielx/civet/register source.civet
```

TITLE: Label Syntax in Civet

SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
:label while (true) {
  break label
}
```

```

CODE:

worker = new Worker(new URL('./worker.civet.tsx', import.meta.url))

x +
y
- z
-negative
[array]
.length
{name: value}
```

TITLE: Configuring Civet for Astro Workers
DESCRIPTION: Configuration for enabling Civet in Astro's Web Worker build process by adding the Vite plugin to vite.worker.plugins option.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/source/unplugin/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
// astro.config.ts
import { defineConfig } from 'astro/config'
import civet from '@danielx/civet/astro'
import civetVitePlugin from '@danielx/civet/vite'

// https://astro.build/config
export default defineConfig({
  // ...
  integrations: [
    civet({
      // options
    }),
  ],
  vite: {
    worker: {
      plugins: () => [
        civetVitePlugin({
          // options
        }),
      ],
      // format: "es",  // if using { type: 'module' }
    },
  },
})
```

TITLE: Configuring Jest for Civet Files in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Example Jest configuration file (jest.config.mjs) that enables testing of Civet files by adding the .civet extension to the list of supported file extensions and configuring the civet-jest transformer.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/integration/jest/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
import {defaults} from 'jest-config'

export default {
  extensionsToTreatAsEsm: [ '.civet' ],
  moduleFileExtensions: [ ...defaults.moduleFileExtensions, 'civet' ],
  testMatch: [ '<rootDir>/test/**/*.civet' ],
  transform: {
    '\\.civet': 'civet-jest',
  },
  verbose: true,
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Metro and Babel for Civet in React Native
DESCRIPTION: This diff shows the necessary changes to metro.config.js and babel.config.js files to enable Civet support in a React Native project. It adds the .civet extension to Metro's source extensions and includes the Civet Babel plugin.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/integration/metro/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: diff
CODE:
```
// include .civet files to module resolution in metro.config.js
-const config = {};
+const config = {
+  resolver: {
+    sourceExts: ['js', 'jsx', 'json', 'ts', 'tsx', 'civet'],
+  },
+};

// add plugin in babel.config.js
 module.exports = {
   presets: ['module:@react-native/babel-preset'],
+  plugins: [['@danielx/civet/babel-plugin']],
+  sourceMaps: 'inline',
 };
```

TITLE: Implementing a Custom Hera Transpiler Plugin for Civet
DESCRIPTION: Example of how to create a custom Hera transpiler plugin for the Civet language server. This plugin enables the processing of .hera files by importing the Hera compiler and defining a transpiler object with the appropriate extension, target format, and compile function.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/lsp/README.md#2025-04-17_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import Hera from "@danielx/hera"
const { compile: heraCompile } = Hera

export default {
  transpilers: [{
    extension: ".hera",
    target: ".cjs",
    compile: function (path, source) {
      const code = heraCompile(source, {
        filename: path,
      })

      return {
        code
      }
    }
  }],
}
```

TITLE: Comment Syntax in Civet
DESCRIPTION: Civet supports triple-slash regular expression blocks, so triple-slash comments should generally be avoided except at the start of files for TypeScript triple-slash directives.
SOURCE: https://github.com/DanielXMoore/Civet/blob/main/civet.dev/comparison.md#2025-04-17_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: civet
CODE:
```
/// A comment because at the top of file
if s
  /// not a comment
  ///.exec s
```
